column4: Hi, how can I know whether I need to reboot my server after a kernel update?
uname -a shows the new version
after a kernel update a reboot is needed
then how can I tell what's the kernel I am running or whether an update is installed
i dont think your running system has the new kernel version already...something has changed...even if there were just changes to modules......best is to reboot
what does you make feel a new kernel has been installed?
rypervenche: I think my question is not clear. I will set my system to always do unattended upgrades, so I need to know whether an updated kernel is installed without recording this info manually
that sounds really different :)  edit /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/50unattended-upgrades
specify what packages NOT to upgrade automagically
aha! that file can reboot the system automatically after a certain update! fantastic
no, you just can define there what packages NOT to upgrade unattanded
i dont recommend to do kernel upgrades automagically
there is a line there: Unattended-Upgrade::Automatic-Reboot "false";
I guess this would reboot the system automatically, no?
didnt know..but i still do not recommend to do that
I can understand your point but it's there for a reason, some cases require that
kernel upgrades may brake things....users might be logged in while you are going to reboot...and and and
I know but in my case the server is a backup server and no users are logged in and it's better to fix something after broken that to have someone hacking the server becasue of late upgrade/patch
there are kernel upgrades with no security reason....and guess you are doing backups.....and your auto-reboot ist running while you are doing them ;)
rebooting in the middle of a backup won't cause problems for me. it's incremental so it would continue later anyway
if the system isnt hanging cause of the new kernel ;)
just points to think about...its your decision
I can really understand your points, thanks for your  care
